notesStmt.p: The Sultan’s Daughter in the Flower Garden is a 400-line rhymed couplet text in Middle High German that was probably composed anonymously in the 14th century. Categorized in scholarship as a “Klosterlegende” or monastery legend, but also exhibiting characteristics of saints’ lives, courtship narratives, stories of noble “heathens” who convert, as well as of docta ignorantia (learned ignorance) and Marian literature, the narrative was probably translated from a no longer extant Latin source and is also transmitted in low German prose versions, as well as in song form. While the prose versions have a “modest” transmission in late medieval manuscripts and early modern prints, the songs’ reception stretches into the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. The Middle High German rhymed couplet version presented here appears, however, in only two late fifteenth-century manuscripts: Berlin, Staatsbibiliothek Preussischer Kulturbesitz, mgo 222, dated to after 1475, and Budapest, Bibl. et Archivum P. P. Franciscanorum, Cod. Esztergom 11, dated to around 1500. Both manuscripts were produced in the southern German-speaking areas and tell the following story: After learning of the arrival of a foreign nobleman whom her father wishes her to wed, the daughter of the Sultan of Babylon goes into their beautiful garden. Among the flowers, she marvels at the beauty of the lilies, whereupon an angel appears and recruits her to worship the God who made them, as long as she can commit to complete chastity. She agrees and he whisks her 3000 miles away, instructing her in the Christian mysteries along the way. The angel delivers her to a convent. where she is accepted, baptized, educated, and eventually becomes abbess.

The dominant aspects of the tale situate it most comfortably in the traditions of Marian literature and docta ignorantia narratives. The references to lilies, to chastity, and to the annunciation from the angel in an enclosed garden come into greater relief in the Berlin manuscript compilation, which includes a number of other texts relating to the Marian tradition (e.g., a pater noster exegesis, a treatise about the rosary, a devotion to Mary, a set of Marian miracles, and an allegory about the heart as cloister). This focus corresponds to the known ownership of the manuscript, which, as indicated in the pastedown on the inside front cover, was a reformed convent of Augustinian nuns in Inzigkofen, a town located about 25 miles north of Lake Constance. In contrast, the Budapest manuscript, most likely produced in a Franciscan context, seems more interested in instructing an audience of lay noblemen in the benefits of giving up their sinful behavior and embracing a more chaste existence for the sake of their fate in the afterlife. Accordingly, the other texts included in the Budapest compilation, many more of which are in verse—as opposed to the Berlin manuscript, where only the Sultan’s Daughter text is rhymed—focus on the concepts of sin and confession (e.g., model confession texts, a Latin catalogue of sins, verse prayer for a good end, a Totentanz, the dream vision of Tundalus, a section from the Lucidarius on the afterlife, and two secular rhymed couplet tales: The Count of Savoy and The Knight in the Chapel).

The text is noteworthy more for its content than for its poetic attributes, the rhymes and imagery being relatively mundane. The combination of the variety of narrative models into one tale is of interest, however, as well as the miraculous trajectory of the clever maiden from an object of exchange between men in Babylon to model Christian, scribe, teacher, and ultimately abbess of a German convent. In addition, the focus in the text on the choice to obey the angel, that is, on the maiden’s agency in determining her fate, is also striking.

Poor, Sara S. “Imagining the Origins of a Clever Woman: The ‘Sultanstochter’ and the Path to Learning in the Late Medieval Devotional Book.” In Mendicant Gender Discourse(s) - Comparative Studies, Reti Medievali 41 (forthcoming, 2021).
Thorough introduction to the text, including detailed analysis of manuscript context.

Poor, Sara S. “Women Teaching Men in the Medieval Devotional Imagination.” In Partners in Spirit: Women, Men, and Religious Life in Germany, 1100-1500, edited by Fiona J. Griffiths and Julie Hotchin. Turnhout, Belgium: Brepols, 2014. 339–65.
Readings of late medieval German narratives of docta ignorantia featuring women, the manuscripts that transmit them, and the historical context.
Morgan, Ben. “The Pleasure of the Text: What Two Manuscripts Can Tell Us About Becoming God.” Medieval Mystical Theology 23, no. 1 (2014): 52–64.
Examination of the Kirchheim reception of the related narrative, the Sister Catherine Treatise, with a focus on its theological content.
Winston-Allen, Anne. Stories of the Rose: The Making of the Rosary in the Middle Ages. University Park, Penn: Pennsylvania State University Press, 1997.

Informative study of the late medieval Marian literature through the evolution of the rosary and the poems, texts, and gardens associated with it. Includes excellent bibliography and also many illustrations.

projectDesc.p: "The Sultan's Daughter in the Flower Garden" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS) , a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

The Middle High German text supplied here is based on Johannes Bolte’s 1890 edition, published in the Zeitschrift für deutsches Altertum (volume 34, pages 18-31), which is a diplomatic transcription of the Berlin manuscript (fols. 160r–170v). I have adopted Bolte’s diacritics where possible. These include the regular umlaut as well as an accent aigu (´), which Bolte also used to indicate an umlauted vowel (presumably because the superscript e in the manuscript looks more like an accent than an e). Dipthongized vowels like a, u, and o, which in the manuscript are indicated with superscripts, have been written out as av, uo, and ov. Superscript abbreviations for er, en, and em have been written out as well. The manuscript often uses a v to represent the vowel u and when this is umlauted, that is also indicated with what looks like an accent (instead of the umlaut or an e over the vowel). In the transcription here, these have been changed to ú (as in úmmer and úber). Bolte’s suggestions for emendations have been adopted and appear in square brackets. My own interjections appear in parentheses. I have also consulted, where necessary, both manuscripts as well as Vizkeletey’s edition of the Budapest manuscript published in 2013 (András Vizkelety, “‘Die Sultanstochter im Blumengarten’ in einer ehemaligen Güssinger Handschrift (A szultánkisasszony a virágok közt. Verses novella egy Németújvárról elszármazott kódexben); Tanulmányok Mollay Károly születésének 100. évfordulójára [Studien zum 100. Geburtstag von Karl Mollay],” Soproni Szemle [Ödenburger Rundschau] 4 (2013): 440–53), as indicated in the footnotes.

app.rdg: He [then] surrounded her in a bright light,

app.lem: ainen brieff gab er ir do in die hand,
app.rdg: and in her hand, he put a letter

app.lem: dar an menig schún geschrift was
app.rdg: that contained much beautiful writing —

app.lem: dz edel wunder avne wank,
app.rdg: this noble miracle tale in its entirety;

app.lem: ir baider red kurcz vnd lang
app.rdg: what each of them said, the angel and the good maiden,

app.lem: dez engels vnd der iunkfrovwun guot,
app.rdg: whether brief or lengthy;

app.lem: vnd was sie hett in irem muot,
app.rdg: what she had in her mind;

app.lem: vnd wer si vor was vnd wie si kam dar,
app.rdg: and who she was before and how she came there.

app.lem: dz was schún geschriben an
app.rdg: All that was beautifully written down

app.lem: mit rotem gold, vnd wer es las,
app.rdg: in red gold letters, and whoever read it

app.lem: der sach, daz si ain haidin was
app.rdg: saw that she was a heathen

app.lem: vnd den tovff noch nie empfieng.
app.rdg: and had not yet been baptized.

app.lem: der engel si vor dem altar lie;
app.rdg: The angel left her in front of the altar.

app.lem: dise red, die er mit ir tett,
app.rdg: She found the teaching that he had given her

app.lem: ducht si minneclich vnd súss.
app.rdg: lovely and sweet.

app.lem: der engel si vil geren sach,
app.rdg: She gladly gazed at the angel.

app.lem: vil zartlich vnd schuon si zuo im sprach:
app.rdg: Very tenderly and beautifully she said to him:

app.lem: ach lieber herr vnd engel min,
app.rdg: “Ah, my dear lord and angel,

app.lem: lavss mich dir enpholchen sin;
app.rdg: Allow me to be received by you,

app.lem: ich havn mich dir ergeben gar,
app.rdg: I have given myself to you completely,

app.lem: nim min in minen nöten war!
app.rdg:
Take me in my moment of need!
The verb is again “warnemen” and her address here to the angel echoes the language of marriage/sex that she rejected with the earthly lord. No doubt, this serves as evidence for the reader that she is still a heathen, a novice in Christian behavior, and that she still has a lot to learn.

app.lem: din red ist zuker súss,
app.rdg: Your words are as sweet as sugar,

app.lem: minen herren du mir grúss;
app.rdg: Greet my lord for me;

app.lem: mit dienst bin ich im berait,
app.rdg: I am ready to serve Him,

app.lem: mit willeklicher arbait.
app.rdg: With willing toil.

app.lem: wan vatter vnd muoter vnd magen min,
app.rdg: For your sake I am leaving

app.lem: die lassen ich durch den willen din,
app.rdg: my father, mother, and kin

app.lem: grossen richtum lavss ich faren.
app.rdg: and I am letting go of great wealth.

app.lem: sag im, er sóll mich wol bewaren!
app.rdg: Tell Him to protect me well!

app.lem: vnd [grúss] ovch mir die maget súss,
app.rdg: And also greet the sweet virgin [Mary] from me,

app.lem: von der du mir vil havst geseit,
app.rdg: about whom you have told me so much,

app.lem: die die kúnschait des ersten anfieng;
app.rdg: and who was the first to be chaste;

app.lem: sag ir, durch ir kind sitz ich hie
app.rdg: Tell her, I have sat down and am sitting here

app.lem: vnd si allain gesessen,
app.rdg: because of her child and her alone,

app.lem: si sol min nit vergessen;
app.rdg: and that she should not forget me.

app.lem: dz zimpt iren gnavden wol,
app.rdg: That would befit her great compassion well,

app.lem: wan ich nit waiss, wav ich sol.
app.rdg: for otherwise, I do not know where I should (turn).”

app.lem: vil zartlich schied er do von ir,
app.rdg: Then he very tenderly took his leave.

app.lem: er sprach: wiss, iunkrow, got ist mit dir.
app.rdg: He said: “Know this, maiden, God is with you.”

app.lem: Nun wist si nit, wa siú sass,
app.rdg: Now, she did not know where she was,

app.lem: diú sprach des landes ir unbekant wz.
app.rdg: nor was the language of the land familiar to her.

app.lem: diú áptissinn des closters da
app.rdg: The abbess of the cloister

app.lem: diu kam gegangen iesa
app.rdg: came along just then

app.lem: navch ir aller gewonhait
app.rdg: which was her regular habit —

app.lem: sú was táglich des ersten berait,
app.rdg: She was always the first to be ready

app.lem: da man got dienen solt,
app.rdg: when it was time to sing the office.

app.lem: in dem kor si wolt.
app.rdg: (And so) she headed to the choir.

app.lem: do siu aller erst tratt hin in,
app.rdg: At the moment she stepped into the choir,

app.lem: si sach die maget vnd den schin;
app.rdg: She saw the maiden surrounded by light;

app.lem: vil bald kert siú sich wider uss,
app.rdg: She turned around quickly and went back out.

app.lem: siu liuff bald in das schlavfhuss,
app.rdg: She sped to the dormitory

app.lem: diu frowan siu bald wakt
app.rdg: Where she immediately woke the ladies, though calmly

app.lem: vil schuon, dz si si nit erschrakti.
app.rdg: So that they wouldn’t be alarmed.

app.lem: do siu si all ze samen bravcht,
app.rdg: When she had brought them all together,

app.lem: siu seit in, was si sach vnd bedavcht;
app.rdg: She told them what she saw and thought;

app.lem: siu sprach: ich wil hiut veriechen,
app.rdg: She said: “I want to tell you today,

app.lem: ich havn Mariun selb gesechen,
app.rdg: That I have seen Mary herself,

app.lem: diu wil úns hiut erun;
app.rdg: She wants to honor us today;

app.lem: zuo der sond wir keren
app.rdg: We should return to her

app.lem: vnd sóllent si enphavchen.
app.rdg: And should welcome her.”

app.lem: siu begund vor an hin gavchen,
app.rdg: She rushed ahead of them,

app.lem: nach ir was gavch in allen,
app.rdg: and all of them rushed after her

app.lem: si hettent sich navch erfallen.
app.rdg: so fast that they almost fell down.

app.lem: si savchent die iunkfrovwen sin
app.rdg: They saw the maiden

app.lem: vil herlich sitzen in iren schin.
app.rdg: Sitting nobly in the light.

app.lem: si vielent fúr si an ir knie,
app.rdg: They fell to their knees before her,

app.lem: Salue regina sungent si,
app.rdg: [and] sang the Salve Regina,

app.lem: dz betút: gotwilkomen kúnginn,
app.rdg: which means: “God welcome you, Queen.

app.lem: von vns solt du gegrússet sin.
app.rdg: May you receive our greeting!”

app.lem: hie von ich nit me sagen wil.
app.rdg: About that I have nothing more to say.

app.lem: der eren was ir doch ze vil,
app.rdg: This honor was of course too much for her (the maiden).

app.lem: súss sungent ir múnd rot,
app.rdg: Their red mouths sang sweetly

app.lem: den brief siu der áptissinen bot.
app.rdg: as she offered the letter to the abbess

app.lem: vil bald siu den úber las
app.rdg: who read through it quickly

app.lem: vnd las, wie es ergangen was.
app.rdg: and saw how things had gone.

app.lem: diss wunders wavrent sie alle frow,
app.rdg: They were all happy about this miracle

app.lem: dz si got geeret hett also
app.rdg: that God had thus honored them

app.lem: fúr allú klóster in dem land,
app.rdg: above all other cloisters in the land

app.lem: den er sóllich botschaft litzel sant;
app.rdg: to which He had sent no such message;

app.lem: vil fród an iren hertzen lag,
app.rdg: Their hearts were filled with great joy

app.lem: si erbietten des tags.
app.rdg: (while) they waited for the day to dawn.

app.lem: ir aller sprách was ir vnkund,
app.rdg: Their language was entirely unknown to her,

app.lem: vil schier funden si den fund,
app.rdg: and so the sisters very quickly realized

app.lem: dz si hain santent in die statt
app.rdg: that they should send a messenger into the city,

app.lem: ainen botten, der den bischof batt,
app.rdg: who would ask the bishop

app.lem: das er kám zuo in dar
app.rdg: to come to them

app.lem: vnd des wunders námi war.
app.rdg: and see the miracle.

app.lem: vil pfaffent er do zuo im nam,
app.rdg: The Bishop gathered many clerics around him

app.lem: mit fróden er do zuo in kam,
app.rdg: and then gladly went to them.

app.lem: den brief er do úber lass,
app.rdg: He then read through the letter

app.lem: er sach, das si ain haidin was
app.rdg: and saw that she was a heathen

app.lem: vnd das diss alles got wolt,
app.rdg: and that God wished

app.lem: das man si da tóffen solt.
app.rdg: her to be baptized.

app.lem: do er den brief hett vss gelesen,
app.rdg: When he had read the letter to the end,

app.lem: er wolt do selb ir tott wesen
app.rdg: He himself wanted to be her Godfather

app.lem: vnd töft si selb mit siner hand
app.rdg: and he baptized her with his own hand

app.lem: vff der fart. diú äptissin si tovd fand
app.rdg: while he was there. The abbess

app.lem: an allen sachen,
app.rdg:
found her dead
The Berlin manuscript has “tõd” here, which could be a mis-writing of “totte” or “tottin” (meaning patroness or Godmother). See footnote 11 for the reading of the Budapest manuscript.

app.lem: als man ain gaistlich mensch
app.rdg: in (to?) all things,

app.lem: sol machen.
app.rdg:
as a spiritual person should be.
It's possible some lines are missing here. The Budapest manuscript has the following for this passage, which is also somewhat difficult to interpret: “Er pesneid si do in weis gewand/ Das pracht man dar mit list/ Sy stuend czu der selben frist/ vnd auch auf der selben vart/ die aptissin do ir got ward/ Do sy nun was christin worden/ Do gaben sy ir den orden.” (Then he dressed her in white clothing -- that was cleverly done -- She stood at the same time and at the same time, the abbess then became her Godmother. When she had become a Christian, the abbess gave (taught) her the rule.)

app.lem: do si was crastan worden,
app.rdg: When she had become a Christian,

app.lem: do gab siu ir den orden
app.rdg: she (the abbess) then gave her the rule

app.lem: vnd die pfrúnd zem kloster.
app.rdg: and her dowry to the cloister.

app.lem: da man schloft sy in gewand,
app.rdg: Then they dressed her in a robe

app.lem:
daz wz graw — — — —
Bolte assumes missing text here, as well as an additional missing line (not included in the line count).
app.rdg: That was gray. — — —

app.lem: si wavrent all des wunders frow,
app.rdg: They were all happy about the miracle

app.lem: Te deum laudamus sungent si do,
app.rdg: and then they sang Te deum laudamus,

app.lem: die priester alt vnd iung
app.rdg: all the priests, old and young

app.lem: vnd di gantz samnung,
app.rdg: and the whole assembly.

app.lem: diss lob si sungent avne spott
app.rdg: They sang this earnestly

app.lem: der rosen vnd der gilgen got.
app.rdg: to the God of roses and lilies.

app.lem: dar navch hiess man si leren,
app.rdg: After that they had her taught –

app.lem: ir hail dz wolt sich meren;
app.rdg: her holiness wanted to grow!

app.lem: siu gelernet in kurtzer frist,
app.rdg: She learned in a short time

app.lem: dz siu kund aller hand list
app.rdg: that she had all kinds of ability

app.lem: singen, lesen vnd schriben,
app.rdg: In singing, reading, and writing,

app.lem: ir tugent was mengualt vnd grovss,
app.rdg: Her virtue was manifold and great:

app.lem: allú wisshait ir zuo floss.
app.rdg: all wisdom flowed to her.

app.lem: diu áptissin dar navch starb,
app.rdg: Soon thereafter, the abbess died.

app.lem: ir lútzel navch ir ampt warb,
app.rdg: Few of the sisters applied for her office,

app.lem: wan si ducht allgemain,
app.rdg: For it seemed to them all

app.lem: wie disiu iunkfrow rain
app.rdg: that this pure maiden

app.lem: vnder in diu best wár úber all;
app.rdg: was the best of all among them.

app.lem: dar zuo gäben si die wal,
app.rdg: For this reason, they voted

app.lem: dz si diu áptissin sólt sin,
app.rdg: that she should be the abbess

app.lem: diu da vor was ein ha[i]
app.rdg: who had previously been a heathen.

app.lem: niement hie voll sagen kan,
app.rdg: No one here can really say

app.lem: wes glúks dz kloster do gewan
app.rdg: how much good fortune the convent won

app.lem: an eren vnd an guot,
app.rdg: in honor and in goodness because of this.

app.lem: dz geschuof diu wolgemuot;
app.rdg: This created an atmosphere of good will and well-being.

app.lem: mit wishiat kund siu des klosters pflegen,
app.rdg: She was able to manage the cloister with wisdom,

app.lem: got der het ir sinen segen
app.rdg: for God had sent her his blessing

app.lem: vnd alles hail zuo gesent.
app.rdg: and everything holy.

app.lem: wie schön si das wolt, si lert
app.rdg: As beautifully as she wanted, she taught

app.lem: si all tugend nacht vnd tag,
app.rdg: them all the virtues night and day;

app.lem: wie lútzel si dar an erlag.
app.rdg: How little she lay down on the job!

app.lem: von kúnschait lert si zuo aller zit,
app.rdg: She taught of chastity at all times:

app.lem: siu lert, was genavd dar an lit;
app.rdg: She taught about the grace that is inherent in it;

app.lem: von der kúnschait besunder
app.rdg: and of chastity in particular,

app.lem: seit siu menig wunder,
app.rdg: she told many miracle stories,

app.lem: wan dz was ir vil wol kunt
app.rdg: for these were made known to her

app.lem: worden von des engels mund.
app.rdg: by the angel’s mouth.

app.lem: ir ler was guot vnd rain,
app.rdg: Her teaching was good and pure

app.lem: noch sússer denne der huonig sain,
app.rdg: even sweeter than honey.

app.lem: siu lert si allen, das si sturben,
app.rdg: She taught them all, so that when she died

app.lem: dz si gottes huld erwurben.
app.rdg: She would attain God’s favor.

app.lem: siu was áptissin drissig iar,
app.rdg: She was abbess for thirty years,

app.lem: siu dienot got avn alle swavr.
app.rdg: serving God without any difficulty.

app.lem: der engel dar navch zuo ir kam,
app.rdg: At the end of this time, the angel who had

app.lem: der si dórt vss dem garten nam,
app.rdg: taken her out of the garden came to her

app.lem: er sprach: iunkfrow, diu zit ist hie,
app.rdg: and said: “Maiden, the time has come,

app.lem: du havst misstretten nie,
app.rdg: You have never had a misstep,

app.lem: du havst behalten min gebott;
app.rdg: and have followed my orders;

app.lem: der rosen vnd der gilgen got
app.rdg: The God of roses and lilies

app.lem: havt mich gesant zuo dir,
app.rdg: has sent me to you —

app.lem: her navch dir stavt mins hertzen begir.
app.rdg: my heart’s desire is longing for you.

app.lem: du solt dich cristanlich bewaren,
app.rdg: See that you keep Christian rule

app.lem: so wil ich bald navch dir faren
app.rdg: and I will come for you soon,

app.lem: von hút an dem dritten tag,
app.rdg: three days from today.

app.lem: da von merk eben, was ich dir sag.
app.rdg: Mark you well what I tell you now:

app.lem: so erzaig wir dir, das ich dir verhiess,
app.rdg: in this way we will fulfill the promise I made you

app.lem: do du den haiden faren liest.
app.rdg: When you left the heathen.”

app.lem: dú iunkfrow ward der red frow,
app.rdg: This speech made the maiden happy,

app.lem: sinem sússen rat folget siu do,
app.rdg: and so she followed his sweet counsel

app.lem: die frowan hiess si kommen dar.
app.rdg: and called the ladies to her.

app.lem: do kament si vnd nament war,
app.rdg: When they came and heard

app.lem: was siu in seit an der stund,
app.rdg: what she said at that moment,

app.lem: in ward ain laidiges már kunt.
app.rdg: a sad tale was made known to them.

app.lem: siu gab in do iren getrúwen ravt,
app.rdg: She gave them her true counsel,

app.lem: si hiess si baidú frú vnd spavt
app.rdg: she bid them love God diligently

app.lem: got flisseclichen minnen
app.rdg: both morning and night

app.lem: mit hertzen vnd sinnen
app.rdg: with heart and mind,

app.lem: vnd mit fliss all tugent havn,
app.rdg: and keenly uphold all the virtues,

app.lem: so mócht es in och wol ergavn.
app.rdg: so that it would go well for them.

app.lem: ir aller iavmer der was grovss,
app.rdg: Their shared grief was so great

app.lem: das wasser inen vss den ovgen floss
app.rdg: that tears flowed out of their eyes,

app.lem: sie wundent all ir hend;
app.rdg: and they wounded all of their hands (from wringing).

app.lem: hie nam ir gewalt ain end,
app.rdg: Thus ended her rule (as abbess):

app.lem: des dritten tags do lag si tovd,
app.rdg: On the third day she lay dead,

app.lem: also schied sy von aller novt.
app.rdg: and she departed from all sorrow.

app.lem: des selben tags kam der engel
app.rdg: On the same day, the angel came

app.lem: vnd nam ir sel zartlich mit im
app.rdg: and gently took her soul with him

app.lem: und fuort si in das himelrich
app.rdg: and led her to heaven

app.lem: zuo andren mágten minneclich,
app.rdg: to the other loving maidens.

app.lem: da ward er all ir fród gantz,
app.rdg: In this way, he became the fulfillment of all their joy:

app.lem: er fuort si an der iunkfrowan tantz.
app.rdg: He brought her to the dance of the virgins.

app.lem: gross iamer sich hie huob,
app.rdg: Great lament arose here (on earth)

app.lem: vil erlich man si do begruob,
app.rdg: as they buried her with honor

app.lem: ob irem grab si sungen:
app.rdg: and sang over her grave:

app.lem: ir ist recht wol gelungen.
app.rdg: She had had a great success:

app.lem: got selber gen ir gie
app.rdg: God himself had gone to her;

app.lem: gar wunneclich vnd minneclich er sie empfieng,
app.rdg: joyfully and full of love he had received her

app.lem: er fuort si an der engel schar:
app.rdg: and led her to the host of angels.

app.lem: got helff vns allen zuo ir dar.
app.rdg: God help us all to join her.

app.lem: Diss sol man geren hóren lesen,
app.rdg: This [tale] should be gladly heard told

app.lem: der der kúnschait dester hólder well wesen;
app.rdg: To anyone who wishes to be that much more beholden to chastity;

app.lem: wan wer die kúnschait lieb havt,
app.rdg: For whoever holds chastity dear,

app.lem: dem mag es hie och wol ergavn,
app.rdg: for him it will go well in this life,

app.lem: wer sich ir versummet havt,
app.rdg: Whoever neglects it,

app.lem: dem wil ich geben den ravt,
app.rdg: him I would counsel

app.lem: das er si geren behalt;
app.rdg: to preserve it gladly;

app.lem: wan got der kúnschait walt
app.rdg: For God governs chastity

app.lem: vnd die vil lieb muoter sin,
app.rdg: and His very dear mother,

app.lem: die hoch himel kúnigin vnd kaiserin,
app.rdg: the high Queen and Empress of heaven,

app.lem: die wz die erst, die kúnschait erkos,
app.rdg: she was the first to choose chastity.

app.lem: da von ir hail ist worden grovss,
app.rdg: because of which her holiness has greatly increased

app.lem: dar nach vil menig iunkfrow her,
app.rdg: and after which very many maidens followed her,

app.lem: dis von ir havnd genomen ler.
app.rdg: (that is, they followed) this lesson from her hand.

app.lem: den kúnschen git si hochen lon,
app.rdg: She gives high praise to the chaste ones,

app.lem: sie setzt in vff der mágte kron.
app.rdg: she places the maidenly crown upon their heads.

app.lem: wer aber sich ir versummet havt,
app.rdg: However, he who has neglected it,

app.lem: der tuo sich der vnkúnsch wider ab
app.rdg: if he rids himself once again of corruption

app.lem: vnd hab dar an vil státten muot,
app.rdg: and then is very steadfast in this,

app.lem: so mag sin ding noch werden guot.
app.rdg: then things can improve for him.

app.lem: wer unkúnsch lavt, e das sú in laut,
app.rdg: Whoever relinquishes corruption, before it spoils him,

app.lem: eye wie wol es im ergavt!
app.rdg: ah, how well it will go for him!

app.lem: dz sag ich mannen vnd wiben,
app.rdg: This I say to men and women:

app.lem: das si vil stát dar an beliben
app.rdg: that they remain steadfast in this

app.lem: vnd folgen miner lere [n]
app.rdg: and follow my teaching

app.lem: vnd sich da von kere [n].
app.rdg: and turn away from corruption.

app.lem: her Salomon gesprochen havt,
app.rdg: Lord Solomon has said

app.lem: das fliechen si der beste ravt.
app.rdg:
that being clean is the best advice.
Cleanliness is next to Godliness?

app.lem: wer kúnsche beliben well vnd das mag tuon,
app.rdg: Whoever wants to and is able to remain chaste,

app.lem: dem git got grovssen luon.
app.rdg: God will give him great praise.

app.lem: got der git im die obrosten kruon
app.rdg: God will give him the highest crown

app.lem: in sinem hóchsten tron.
app.rdg: in his highest throne.

app.lem: da mit havt diss buoch ain end,
app.rdg: Herewith the book is at an end,

app.lem: got vns sinen hailigen segen send
app.rdg: may God send us His holy blessing

app.lem: vnd verlich vns allen ain guotes end. Amen
app.rdg: and solemnly grant us all a good end. Amen
